CV

I used vigastama 'to hurt' instead of lõikama 'to cut' here, because Peeter lõikas ennast 'Peeter cut himself (partitive)' would leave the impression that the cutting was done on purpose, while vigastama does not have the same connotation. Another solution would be Peeter lõikas endale ... 'Peeter cut himself (allative) ...', but in this case we'd need to specify where he cut himself to make it sound natural, e.g. kätte 'into his hand'.

back_translation_en: ‘The glass got stuck to the table.’

in general, kuulama 'to listen' requires the partitive, the genitive/nominative only occurs with particles or resultative complements like ära or lõpuni 'to the end'

An alternative is "sõna kuulama", but it could not be included in the database because Y would have been expressed as an NP-internal modifier: Peeter kuula-b alati oma ema sõna [PN.SG.NOM listen-PRS.3SG always POSS.REFL mother.SG.GEN word.SG.PART], lit. ‘Peeter always listens to his mother's word.’ (Note also that sõna is a noun, not a postposition (unlike külge, üle, suhtes, etc.)).

back_translation_en: ‘The honey got mixed with the milk.’

comms_internal: like kuulama, vaatama 'to look/watch' requires the partitive, unless there is some kind of particle (üle 'over', läbi 'through', lõpuni 'to the end' etc)

MN: "It's a very tricky one, mainly because it usually occurs with numbers and currencies. With numbers greater than 1, the number is in the nominative case and the noun in the partitive (triggered by the preceding number), e.g. see maksa-b kaks euro-t DEM.SG.NOM cost-PRS.3SG two.SG.NOM euro-SG.PART 'This costs two euros'. With negation, ... that is both are possible, ... It seems like there is slight difference in meaning; the [nominative] means that the exact price is not 2 euros (it could be more or less than that), while the [partititve] indicates that it doesn't (even) cost 2 euros (it's cheaper than that)... on a second thought we both agreed that while the original translation (see tops maksa-b üks euro DEM.SG.NOM cup.SG.NOM cost-PRS.3SG one.SG.NOM euro.SG.NOM) also works, it'd actually be even better to use the genitive case here... And if we turn away from numbers and currencies, we find many examples with the genitive (where the nominative would not be possible at all) ...see maksab ühe inimese elu või surma 'it costs the life (GEN) or death (GEN) of a person' ... I'd still label this verb as transitive, even though it does behave differently than other transitive verbs in certain contexts
like that, the sentence does not contain information on whether P. missed the bird or not
